name: Cyclobutadiene

energies.comment: ANTIAROMATIC - 4 π-electrons (4n, n=1). Extremely unstable, only isolated at 8K in matrix or as metal complex. Total bond energy calculated from experimental heat of formation. CRITICAL TEST: If feedback loop hypothesis is correct, this should show large NEGATIVE violation similar in magnitude to benzene's positive violation. NOTE: Wu et al. (2012) suggests ring strain (251 kJ/mol) >> antiaromatic destabilization (69 kJ/mol), so this confounds geometric and electronic effects.
energies.source: Fattahi et al., Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. 2006, 45(30):4984-4988

alternative_experimental_value.note: Disagrees with Fattahi by 49 kJ/mol. Different methodology. Larger uncertainty.

energies.confidence_note: Experimental measurement but with methodological disagreement between two primary sources (49 kJ/mol discrepancy). Using Fattahi (2006) as primary due to tighter error bounds and more recent methodology.

reference_energies.comment: Standard bond energies (kJ/mol) for naive calculation. Naive = 2(C=C) + 2(C-C) + 4(C-H) = 2(602) + 2(346) + 4(413) = 3548 kJ/mol

notes: Cyclobutadiene is THE canonical example of antiaromatic destabilization
4 π-electrons violates Hückel's 4n+2 rule (this is 4n where n=1)
Extremely reactive - dimerizes instantly at room temperature
Only stable at 8K in inert gas matrix or as metal-coordinated complex
Predicted violation: -150 to -200 kJ/mol (destructive interference in feedback loop)
ACTUAL violation (Fattahi 2006): -237 ± 16 kJ/mol → STRONGER than predicted ✓
ACTUAL violation (Deniz 1999): -286 ± 46 kJ/mol → MUCH STRONGER than predicted ✓
Magnitude: 1.6-1.9× benzene's +148 kJ/mol (opposite sign as expected)
If feedback loop hypothesis is correct: same mechanism as benzene but OPPOSITE SIGN
Bond orders shown as 1.5 represent delocalized but antiaromatic system
This tests whether cycles create correlation feedback that can be constructive OR destructive
CAVEAT: Wu et al. (2012) suggests ring strain dominates over antiaromaticity
Therefore this test confounds geometric (ring strain) and electronic (antiaromatic) correlation
